docs.lead_paragraph: The three-year agreements with the Communications Workers of America provide for wage increases, but full details were not released.

headline.seo: AT&T and Union Reach Tentative Pacts for 2 Units
headline.main: Two Units of AT&T Reach Pacts With Union
headline.print_headline: Two Units Of AT&T Reach Pacts With Union

docs.abstract: AT&T announces it has reached tentative three-year contract agreements with the Communications Workers of America, which represents more than 13,000 workers in its Midwest division, and an additional 5,700 workers at another unit; union applauds agreements, saying they do not contain the deep concessions many American companies are demanding.
docs.snippet: The three-year agreements with the Communications Workers of America provide for wage increases, but full details were not released.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act brings various cost savings, but much more legislative work is needed to find others, says Christina D. Romer.

headline.seo: Health Care Law and Cost Containment — Economic View
headline.main: Only the First Step in Containing Health Costs
headline.print_headline: Only the First Step In Containing Health Costs

docs.abstract: Christina D Romer Economic View column notes that despite the considerable progress made by the Affordable Health Care Act, health care spending is still projected to rise rapidly over the coming decades; calls on legislators to strengthen existing cost-saving measures and to explore others.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act brings various cost savings, but much more legislative work is needed to find others, says Christina D. Romer.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael O. Leavitt’s work on insurance exchanges has upset conservatives who want states to resist the Affordable Care Act.

headline.seo: Romney Aide Leavitt Advises States to Prepare Health Care Plans
headline.main: Romney Aide Helps States Comply With Health Care Law
headline.print_headline: Romney Aide Advises On State Health Plans

docs.abstract: Michael O Leavitt, one of presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's top aides, has spent two years advising states and private insurers on how to comply with the health care law, but his work has caused consternation among some conservatives, who want states to resist the Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: Michael O. Leavitt’s work on insurance exchanges has upset conservatives who want states to resist the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A health care system owned and managed by Alaska’s native people has achieved astonishing results in improving the health of its enrollees while cutting the costs of treating them.

headline.seo: A Formula for Cutting Health Costs
headline.main: A Formula for Cutting Health Costs
headline.print_headline: A Formula for Cutting Health Costs

docs.abstract: Editorial highlights the astonishing results achieved by the Southcentral Foundation, a health care system owned and managed by Alaska's native people that has improved the health of its enrollees while cutting costs; identifies many of the techniques for improving the quality and cost of delivering health care that any other system can adopt.
docs.snippet: A health care system owned and managed by Alaska’s native people has achieved astonishing results in improving the health of its enrollees while cutting the costs of treating them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia, with one of the nation’s worst infection rates, is offering tests in grocery stores, high schools and motor vehicle offices — and paying people to take them.

headline.seo: Washington, D.C., Tests for AIDS in Stores, Streets and Offices
headline.main: In Washington, H.I.V. Testing Moves Beyond the Clinic
headline.print_headline: Testing for H.I.V. at Stores, on Street Corners and at the Motor Vehicle Office

docs.abstract: Washington DC's innovative AIDS treatment and prevention program, which includes free testing, community outreach, condom distribution and needle exchange, is slowing spread of the disease in a city that has one of the nation's worst infection rates; district will host an International AIDS Society conference, the world's biggest gathering devoted to the disease.
docs.snippet: The District of Columbia, with one of the nation’s worst infection rates, is offering tests in grocery stores, high schools and motor vehicle offices — and paying people to take them.

headline.print_headline: Flanked by Green, Edged in Blue

headline.seo: ‘The Cost of Hope,’ by Amanda Bennett
